>> David Ferriero: Good afternoon and welcome
to the William G. McGowan Theater at The National

440.text:
Archives. I am David Ferriero, the Archivist
of the United States, and I am pleased that

444.text:
you can join us today, whether you are here
in person or watching us on our YouTube channel.

449.text:
Before we get started with today's program,
I would like to tell you about two other book

455.text:
discussions coming up here this week. Tomorrow
at noon we will host the national book launch

460.text:
of JFK: A Vision for America. JFK's nephew,
Stephen Kennedy Smith and historian, Doug

466.text:
Brinkely have brought together Kennedy's greatest
speeches, along with essays by America's leading

472.text:
historians, political thinkers and writers
and artists. The next day, Thursday, May 4,

477.text:
at 7 p.m. author David Dalin will speak about
the eight Jewish men and women, who served

484.text:
as justices of the Supreme Court, and who
are featured in his book: The Jewish Justices

490.text:
of the Supreme Court: From Brandeis to Kagan.
To learn about these and all of our public

495.text:
programs and exhibits, consult our monthly
Calendar of Events in print or online at archives.gov.

503.text:
There are copies in the lobby as well as a
sign‑up sheet where you can receive it by

507.text:
regular mail or E‑mail.
Food is a basic human need, but its place

516.text:
in culture stretches far beyond fulfilling
nutritional requirements. The act of preparing

522.text:
and sharing a meal brings people together
and cultivates bonds among them. Several years

527.text:
ago in an exhibit "What is cooking, Uncle
Sam?" The National Archives explored the federal

532.text:
government's historic involvement in the food
that we eat. Part of that exhibit pulled records

538.text:
from our presidential libraries provided a
glimpse into the cuisine of the White House,

542.text:
both private and public. For those of us who
love both history and good food, the exhibit

548.text:
was an eye opening treat. And today's guest
has given us a further treat in his book on

554.text:
the African‑Americans who fed the presidents
and their families. Since publication of the

560.text:
Presidents Kitchen Cabinet Adrian Miller has
shared his stories of African‑American cooks

564.text:
on NPR, the Washington Post, the Boston Globe,
last night on Fox News, and other media outlets.

571.text:
And now we are pleased that he will be sharing
those stories with us this afternoon. I am

577.text:
especially pleased because Adrian used 12
of our 14 presidential libraries in research

583.text:
for the book.
Adrian Miller is a food writer, attorney and

587.text:
certified BBQ judge who lives in Denver. He
is currently the Executive Director of the

593.text:
Colorado Council of Churches and the first
African‑American and the first layperson

598.text:
to hold that position. Miller previously served
as a special assistant to President Bill Clinton

603.text:
and senior policy analyst for Colorado governor
Bill Reuter, Jr. He has also been a board

609.text:
member of the Southern Foodways Alliance.
His previous books: Soul food: The surprising

615.text: story of American Cuisine One Plate at a Time, won the James Beard award for scholarship and

617.text:
reference in 2014. Ladies and gentlemen, please
welcome Adrian Miller.

625.text:
(APPLAUSE)
>> Adrian Miller: Good afternoon. I am so

636.text:
happy there are more than two people, because
as an author my threshold is two people. If

641.text:
I have more than two, I am happy. So it's
just great to see this turnout here. Thank

645.text:
you. I want to say thank you to AOTUS Ferriero
for the wonderful introduction, and all the

650.text:
other staffers here. The game plan for today,
I am going to tell you about my journey, how

655.text:
I came to write this book. And then I am going
to go through the sequence of the chapters

659.text:
of the book, and share some of my favorite
stories, not all of them because I would love

663.text:
for to you buy the book. We will take questions
after that. So, this is a picture of me in

670.text:
the White House kitchen, with the kitchen
Steward a man named Adam Colic I took it July

677.text:
2015. Has anybody actually ever seen the White
House kitchen? One of the things ‑‑ oh,

682.text:
okay. What is one of the most surprising things
about the White House kitchen?

685.text:
>> It's small.
>> It's small. It's tiny. It's only 30 by

691.text:
26 feet. So there are only a few privileged
people who had a privilege to serve in the

695.text:
kitchen because it doesn't have a lot of space.
But I love the picture. It was my first time

700.text:
in the White House kitchen, even though I
worked in the White House. And I will tell

703.text:
you about that. So as I mentioned, I was born
and raised in Denver, Colorado, which immediately

708.text:
loses me all street cred on the subject of
soul food. The way I win people back is I

714.text:
tell them about my heritage. I have two southern
parents. My mom is from Chattanooga Tennessee,

719.text:
and my dad is from Helena, Arkansas. This
is the food that I grew up eating. So I went

723.text:
to Stanford undergrad, and then Georgetown
for law school. I was practicing law for about

728.text:
four years, and I just really didn't enjoy
it. This is not to disparage any attorneys

731.text:
in the audience, or anybody who has an attorney
in their family, this just wasn't for me.

736.text:
I was singing spirituals in my office, so ‑‑
thank you for laughing at that joke. I figured

742.text:
I needed to do something else. So I was going
to open up a soul food restaurant in Denver,

747.text:
and then I got a call from a Georgetown law
school classmate about the president's initiative

751.text:
for this new thing called One America. It
was in President Clinton's White House, and

756.text:
it was an outgrowth on the President's initiative
on race. The crazy idea behind the President's

762.text:
initiative on race was this: If we just talk
to one another and got to know each other,

767.text:
we might understand we have a lot more in
common than what divides us. So she tells

771.text:
me about the initiative and she asked me if
I had friends back in Denver who ‑‑ or

776.text:
DC, excuse me, who might be interested in
working on this initiative. So, I did the

781.text:
same thing that Dick Cheney did when George
W. Bush asked him to find a Vice‑President.

785.text:
I went on the search committee, only my name
went on the list. So I went to work in the

790.text:
White House, it was a great time. After the
change of the administration, shockingly,

796.text:
George W. Bush was not interested as me as
a Clinton staffer working for him. Job market

800.text:
was a little slow at that time and I was watching
a lot of daytime television. So I thought,

807.text:
I need to read something. So I went to the
book store and I got a book called Southern

810.text:
Food at Home on the Road in History. If you
are a fan of southern food history, I highly

815.text:
encourage this book. It was written by John
Edgerton. In that book he said, the tribute

819.text:
to African‑American achievement in cookery
has yet to be written. I thought that was

824.text:
interesting. I E‑mailed him to see if somebody
had written that history, because the book

828.text:
was about ten years old by the time I read
it. Excuse me. He said, you know, no one has

834.text:
really taken on the full story. So, with no
qualifications at all, except for eating a

838.text:
lot of soul food and cooking it some, I wrote
the book on the history of soul food. And

845.text:
it was really during that research that I
started to learn about the African‑Americans

849.text:
who cooked for our presidents. And they just
jumped off the page at me. So in terms of

853.text:
the research, what I did, I did go to most
of the presidential libraries and looked for

858.text:
any information that the library may have
had on food. And it was really hit or miss.

863.text:
Some libraries were great about the food reports
records. I would say my favorite was Jimmy

866.text:
Carter Presidential Library because for whatever
reason they kept the private menus of what

872.text:
Jimmy Carter ate in the residence. If you
pick a day, and Jimmy Carter was there, you

876.text:
are likely to find out what he had for breakfast,
lunch and dinner. And often there are marginal

881.text:
notes from Rosalynn, like, "Jimmy doesn't
like green peas," and things like that. And

886.text:
the Reagan library was good also in terms
of records. Unless the staff preserving records

891.text:
or the photographers thought what was happening
in the kitchen was interesting, there is not

895.text:
a lot of information about these cooks. So
after I finished the soul food book in 2013,

901.text:
I said, if I could just find enough stories
about these cooks, I would like that to be

905.text:
my next book. It was really a combination
of the presidential research library research,

912.text:
also looking and reading presidential memoirs,
and also the memoirs of staffers that started

918.text:
to rounded out the information. But the real
gold mine was is the old historic newspapers

923.text:
being digitized by the Library of Congress
and private companies because those records

928.text:
are ‑‑ those newspapers are word searchable.
Once you figure out certain names and how

933.text:
they describe cooks in past eras, it just
opened up a whole world to me. And that really

937.text:
rounded out the research. Let's talk about
the White House domestic staff and what it

943.text:
was like for African‑Americans in the presidential
kitchen. So this picture was taken in spring

949.text:
of 1877. Does anybody know who was president
in springs of 1877? You can't answer this.

955.text:
Anybody know who was president in the spring
of 1877?

958.text:
>> (inaudible).
>> Adrian Miller: Yes. Who answered that question?

962.text:
Okay. I should have discounted you as well.
Rutherford B. Hayes. Here we have ‑‑

966.text:
this is the earliest picture we have on the
presidential staff, at least the resident

971.text:
staff. This woman is Winnie Monroe. She was
the Hayes' private cook who comes to the White

979.text:
House after Hayes gets elected. And that pretty
much the journey for most of the presidential

984.text:
cooks that I found. They are pretty much accidental.
They are enslaved or working for somebody

989.text:
who becomes president. Very few examples of
someone who starts a career saying, I want

993.text:
to be a White House chef. Even today. Although,
it may change with the chef celebrity culture.

999.text:
If I were to ascribe a nice metaphor for
the Presidents and food, I would call it the

1004.text:
presidential pickle. Because we want our Presidents
to be extraordinary people, but we also want

1009.text:
them to be a lot like us, and food is a great
metaphor for how we feel about our President.

1015.text:
Presidents who love childhood foods or nostalgic
foods, we think they are more relatable. If

1019.text:
they like fancy food or foreign food, we kind
of think they are out of touch. So, that's

1025.text:
plays out with the presidency. We have had
some Presidents who have had a real keen understanding

1030.text:
of how to use the other symbols to enhance
their presidential personality and power,

1035.text:
and we have others that don't seem to do it
so well. All right. Here is the first person

1041.text:
I will talk about. A man named Samuel Fraunces.
I know what you are thinking as soon as this

1045.text:
picture came up, he looks a lot like a white
dude. Well, his race has been contested by

1050.text:
a lot of historians. But his descendants all
believe him to be a biracial man from the

1055.text:
West Indies, he may have been from Jamaica
or Haiti but he really affected more British

1060.text:
custom, so it's more probable that he is from
Jamaica. He is the first chapter of my boo ‑‑

1067.text:
or second chapter. The first chapter of the
book I show the different elements that go

1071.text:
into presidential food ways and food culture.
I take a Maison plat approach. There are two

1078.text:
kinds of cooks. You probably know cooks that
walk into any kitchen, look into the pantry

1082.text:
or the fridge and they can just create a great
meal. That's not me. I need to have everything

1086.text:
measured out ahead of time and all of my ingredients.
If you go to culinary school, that's called

1091.text:
Maison plat. So I take that approach when
talking about presidential food ways. But

1095.text:
the second chapter, I talk about all the people
who are in charge of running the domestic

1099.text:
operations for the presidential residence.
In the earliest days of the presidency they

1104.text:
were called stewards. Today they are called
the chief usher. The first steward in the

1111.text:
United States history is this man, Samuel
Fraunces. He comes from the West Indies, arrives

1116.text:
in New York City in the 1750s. He was a very
astute businessman, and started running a

1123.text:
pickling and preserving business. Then he
opens up a tavern called Fraunces Tavern.

1128.text:
If you go to New York City you will actually
see a replica of that tavern on 54 Pearl Street

1133.text:
in Lower Manhattan not too far from Wall Street.
So he runs this tavern and has a very famous

1140.text:
patron, General George Washington, who frequently
ate at his tavern and loved his food. When

1147.text:
Washington becomes president, he actually
taps Fraunces to run his household and be

1152.text:
the first presidential steward. They had a
lot of adventures together, and a lot of respect.

1158.text:
When George Washington says farewell to his
troops, he has that farewell party at Fraunces'

1163.text:
tavern. The first thing I wanted to share
with you is called the poison pea plot of

1168.text:
1776. Now I don't know if you learned about
this in grade school or even in college, but

1175.text:
this is actually a mint green pea soup that
is served at the George W. Bush Presidential

1181.text:
Library restaurant. It is excellent. I have
the recipe for this in my book. It was a favorite

1186.text:
of Laura Bush. So, George Washington loved
green peas, in fact so much his contemporaries

1193.text:
called him pea ditty. Okay, I just had to
try it, I had to go for it.

1198.text:
(LAUGHTER)
>> Adrian Miller: Here is the story. The story

1200.text:
is, Fraunces daughter, a woman named Phoebe
is preparing a meal for the general, and it

1206.text:
includes his favorite green peas. There was
a guy named Thomas Hickey who was kind of

1211.text:
hanging around the kitchen. He was not sympathetic
to all this revolutionary talk. And he was

1216.text:
trying to figure out a way to basically poison
the general. So, he is in the kitchen, he

1221.text:
distracts Phoebe and puts extra seasoning
on the peas, and they get sent out to the

1227.text:
table. Phoebe senses something is going on,
she tells her father Samuel Fraunces, and

1232.text:
Fraunces immediately understands what is happening.
He bursts from the kitchen, and just as the

1237.text:
general is about to eat the peas, he grabs
the plate and the fork and throws the peas

1242.text:
out the window. Now at that very same moment
there was a chicken walking by who pecked

1248.text:
at the peas and dies. So thanks to that animal
testing they know the peas were poisoned.

1255.text:
It's a fabulous story but probably not true
for a lot of reasons. One, there was ‑‑

1261.text:
Fraunces did have daughters but we don't have
a record of someone named Phoebe. It could

1264.text:
have been a family nickname. And two, there
was a guy Thomas Hickey, and he was charged

1270.text:
with treason but his crime was really for
counterfeiting not for an assassination attempt.

1275.text:
He was actually hanged in the New York Harbor
in July of 1776 and about 20,000 people showed

1282.text:
up for the execution. But his crime was counterfeiting
and creating passes that may have allowed

1288.text:
other unsavory people to be in the general's
presence and kill him. So it's a great story,

1293.text:
probably not true, but if it is true, ladies
and gentlemen, I submit to you this is the

1297.text:
first act of culinary Homeland Security in
our great nation. Here is another cook, this

1303.text:
is Hercules. Now Hercules was the enslaved
cook for George ‑‑ President George Washington.

1309.text:
And my second chapter talks about the various
enslaved cooks that have worked in the White

1315.text:
House. Because we have had a lot of slave
holding presidents. So Hercules is an interesting

1320.text:
character. I want you to notice a few thing,
I want you to notice his outfit here (indicating).

1326.text:
This is an actual painting that is hanging
in a museum in Spain. The name of the painting

1331.text:
is: A cook for George Washington. It is believed
to be painted by Gilbert Stewart, the same

1337.text:
artist who painted that iconic portrait of
George Washington that so many of us know.

1341.text:
Hercules gets basically purchased by George
Washington when he was a teenager. He was

1347.text:
a ferryman at the time, but for whatever reason
George Washington moves him to the kitchen

1351.text:
in Mount Vernon and has him train under another
enslaved chef, Old Doll. So he cooks for her

1357.text:
for years. When the president moves from New York
to Philadelphia he actually brings Hercules

1364.text:
to Philadelphia and installs him as his cook.
The reason why he did this, is that his first

1369.text:
cook, a white woman named Mrs. Reed, I guess
the food was nasty. He just was not feeling

1373.text:
it. So he fires Mrs. Reed and asks Hercules
to come up and be his cook. There was one

1378.text:
slight problem. Pennsylvania at that time
had something called the Gradual Abolition

1383.text:
Act of 1780, which meant if you were enslaved
person and you were on Pennsylvania soil for

1389.text:
six months or longer, you were automatically
free. So the way that George Washington got

1394.text:
around this, right about the time of the six‑month
deadline, he would pack up all of the enslaved

1398.text:
people, leave them at Mount Vernon, leave
them there a few weeks ‑‑ I know, messed

1403.text:
up, right? He would bring them back and he
did this throughout his presidency. While

1409.text:
in Philadelphia Hercules was given a lot of
liberties. He was allowed to go to the circus.

1414.text:
After work he would get dressed up in a fancy
suit and walk around town with a golden cane.

1420.text:
Also George Washington let him sell leftovers
out of the kitchen. And he made a couple thousand

1424.text:
dollars a year, back then, selling his leftovers,
that was how good the brother's cooking was.

1430.text:
At the end of President Washington's second
term, he suspected Hercules is going to escape.

1436.text:
And so, to punish him, he sends him back to
Mount Vernon, but not to the kitchen. He puts

1441.text:
him in the fields having him make bricks and
other hard labor. So this well renown chef

1449.text:
is now in the field doing hard labor. So on
Washington's 65th birthday, he actually runs

1453.text:
away successfully. And Washington was not
happy about it. If you read accounts from

1458.text:
Washington he could have a volcanic temper.
He was upset. You can tell through the letters

1463.text:
that he wrote to his associates that he was
going through the five stages of grief at

1466.text:
this time. He spared no expense to get Hercules
but never finds him. The question is, where

1472.text:
does Hercules go? Going back to this outfit.
This is the outfit of somebody who would have

1480.text:
been a chef in Europe at that time period,
not in the United States. So it's believed

1485.text:
he may have gone to Europe to sit for the
painting, but we are all speculating, no one

1489.text:
really knows. The last we hear of Hercules
is after Washington dies, he is was spotted

1496.text:
in New York City by the mayor of New York
City, Mayor Barrack, who was actually a personal

1502.text:
secretary of President Washington at one point.
He writes to Martha Washington asking if she

1509.text:
wants him to make an effort to actually recapture
Hercules and brings him back, but Martha never

1514.text:
responds. There was a person who was doing
traveling through the United States who writes

1519.text:
about going to Mount Vernon in the early 1800s,
he encountered one of Hercules' daughters

1525.text:
and he asks her if she misses him or is sad,
and she says no, she is happy because he is

1531.text:
free.
The next person I want to tell you about,

1535.text:
we don't have a visual representation of him,
is James Hemings. James Hemings was never

1539.text:
a presidential chef, but he was an enslaved
cook for Thomas Jefferson. This is actually

1545.text:
a list of utensils at Monticello written in
his own hand. When Jefferson becomes minister

1553.text:
to France in the last 1780s, he actually brings
James Hemings with him, the 19‑year‑old

1557.text:
James Hemings with him to France. James Hemings
was one of two older brothers of Sally Hemings,

1562.text:
who you may have heard of. While in France,
Jefferson spares no expense to actually have

1568.text:
him trained as a chef, spends a lot of money,
spends three years doing this. And installs

1573.text:
him as his resident chef while he is in
Paris. When they come back from Paris through

1580.text:
the United States after a few years in the
mid 1790s Hemings approaches Thomas Jefferson

1587.text:
and says, I want to be free. He agrees to
free him on two conditions: One, you have

1593.text:
to teach the other enslaved cooks back at
Monticello all of the things that you learned.

1598.text:
And two, you have to leave behind your recipes.
Jefferson agrees to do this. After a couple of

1604.text: ‑‑ a year and a half of apprenticeship with the other cooks,  he is freed in 1796. After that, Hemings goes

1610.text:
to other places, may have gone overseas. He
does return to Monticello to cook for a short

1616.text:
period of time, but he never becomes presidential
chef because at age of 31 he drank himself

1622.text:
to death in the City of Baltimore. So a tragic
end for James Hemings. He did shape presidential

1629.text:
food in the early ‑‑ early in the presidential
history. And one of the things that Thomas

1633.text:
Jefferson loved was macaroni and cheese. He
is a macaroni and cheese Jones. Okay? Here

1639.text:
we have a drawing of a macaroni maker. And
Jefferson encounters macaroni while he is

1646.text:
in France and loves the dish. He actually
has one of his aides smuggle a macaroni maker

1650.text:
back to the United States. And smuggle is
an apt description, because Italians had macaroni

1655.text:
making on lockdown. And the earliest macaroni
and cheese recipes was really the pasta with

1662.text:
Parmesan and maybe butter. We know that Jefferson
loved macaroni and cheese because he serves

1668.text:
it in the White House on February 6, 1802.
A man named Manasa Cutler, who was a republican

1675.text:
representative from Massachusetts was at the
dinner. He was an avid diarist, so he actually

1679.text:
describes the meal, and he didn't know what
to make of macaroni and cheese. He thought

1683.text:
the pasta was giant onions. And so he asked
the guy next to him to explain what the dish

1689.text:
was. And that guy was Meriwether Lewis from
the Lewis and Clark expedition. And he explained

1694.text:
what macaroni and cheese was. After this dinner ‑‑
the verdict from Manasa Cutler, after he tasted

1700.text:
it, he said it was strong with a disagreeable
taste. So he wasn't a big fan. After the mac

1706.text:
and cheese meal, Jefferson would take people
into the east room and have them look at a

1710.text:
giant wedge of cheese that he got from some
farmers as an inauguration gift. That was

1715.text:
his idea of fun, you know, look at this literal
ton of cheese. Let's fast forward to talk

1722.text:
about the free cooks that have been in White
House history. So this is after emancipation,

1729.text:
this is Laura Dollie Johnson. That is her
in the middle. This is the big coal‑fired

1737.text: stove that was installed in the 1850 during the Millard Fillmore administration. The story behind the stove is that the African‑American

1744.text:
cook really did not want to cook on the stove
when Millard Fillmore wanted it installed.

1750.text:
The cook at that time was used to doing hearth
cooking, that was cooking in a fireplace with

1755.text:
elevated pots and other things, and just thought
that this was the devil's contraption. I think

1760.text:
that was the term that was used. And supposed
Millard Fillmore went to the patent office,

1764.text:
got instructions for the stove, brought it
back and somehow convinced the cook to actually

1769.text:
start cooking that way with this stove. It's
been in use ever since. Dollie Johnson is

1774.text:
a fascinating character, because she does
not come to the White House as a servant,

1781.text:
or as someone who is directly connected to
the president. She actually has to get talked

1785.text:
into the job. And the way this happened is
a young Politico named Theodore Roosevelt

1790.text:
was traveling through Kentucky, and he went
to a Kentucky colonel's house for dinner,

1795.text:
and Dollie Johnson made the meal. And he was
so impressed by the meal that when Benjamin

1800.text:
Harrison becomes president, he recommends
Dollie Johnson to be his cook. So, there are

1805.text:
a lot of negotiations. Dollie Johnson actually
wanted to start a catering business, not work

1809.text:
at the White House. But they talk her into
coming to the White House. There was only

1812.text:
one small problem. There was already a cook
there. A woman named madam (inaudible), a

1819.text:
French woman, cooking for the British embassy
and then came to work at the White House.

1825.text:
And she did not like the national headlines
announcing Dollie Johnson's hire. So this

1830.text:
very French cook had a very American response.
She went to the press and badmouthed the Harrison's

1836.text:
eating habits. One of the main charges, they
ate a lot of pie all day, and the second thing

1842.text:
she does is filed a lawsuit. So this was earliest
known case of a White House staffer suing

1848.text:
the President. And I don't know how it got
resolved but It ultimately got resolved. It

1853.text:
never got to litigation, but I just thought
that was pretty fascinating. Dollie Johnson

1858.text:
was celebrated in her time. She was known
for her cooking. She got the Harrisons hooked

1862.text:
on southern food classics. And then the interesting
